CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 26, 2019
CommentsContent: My stroller just arrived yesterday. I haven’t had a chance to put it to practical use but so far I love it. It was easy to unfold, simple to put together. I have a small home and was able to maneuver it smoothly and easily.  I love the design. It looks very nice - black with gray accent trim The back of the seat that looks gray in the picture looks more like a very light blue and very pretty. I like that the cup trays are removable from both seats to allow for car seat placement. The front seat doesn’t recline all the way but I couldn’t find a double stroller in my price range that both seats did. It goes back far enough that I think it would still be comfy for sleeping. I love that the back seat reclines all the way. This way baby can be reclined/sleeping in his carrier in the front and my 2yo can still nap in the back seat if needed. One cool part about the back seat bassinet option is there is a flap that you can velcro up so that bottle/toys/blanket don’t fall out the front (would only go into basket below but still nice) It would be nice if the recline positions were adjustable as they each only have up or down but options seem comfy. With baby in front and toddler in the back they will be facing each other which could be good or bad. But there’s always the option to switch them too. The storage basket is a nice size and I like accessability from the back. Only problem is you can’t really access it when the back seat is reclined. My daughter tried to stand up in the basket underneath (not strapped in bc just trying it out) so we will have to see how the durability is there. I have a Baby Trend car seat which although it doesn’t click in it sits deep enough in the seats that I think it will work just fine. It’s a little more difficult to get into the back seat but that’s bc it hits the parent storage compartment and cup holder on the handle but I think that would happen with any seat you use. There is only one cup holder for the parent. My single stroller has two which is nice when mom and dad are both out with baby. My other also has an adjustable handle which is nice bc I’m only 5’2” so I use the lower option but this one still seemed comfortable. The window in the back to see the child is low so you have to stoop down to see through it and there isn’t one in the front seat canopy so you can’t see that child if the canopy is up. Folding is simple. It is large and bulky but it’s a double stroller! I still think it’s pretty light for how big and versatile it is.  I saw in a you tube review that when side by side with a jogging stroller that they are very comparable in length when unfolded. When folded my single jogging stroller fits nicely side to side or front to back in the back of my Honda Pilot with the third row down. I think I will be fine with this one but the back seat canopy does not come off which adds 8-10” when folded compared to my jogging stroller so I think fitting it into a car trunk will be tough (my jogging stroller fit but was difficult in my Mazda 6 and it had a large trunk) and I don’t think it will fit front to back in mine. I compared this stroller with Baby Trend sit n stand and Grace Room2Grow and after lots of research chose this one bc Baby Trend front seat didn’t really recline so if carrier in back toddler wouldn’t be able to be comfortable. When carrier in front and using the bench seat the front seat was back so far that space for the child in the bench seat is infringed making him/her sit up straight and looked uncomfortable. There seemed to be similar issues with space between the seats on the Graco option. I think this one will be comfortable for both children regardless which formation you use. My daughter is 2.5yo. She’s small but fit in the back seat comfortably with the front reclined for baby seat. Overall I really like this stroller. I think the few issues I mentioned won’t be that big of a deal, just wanted to point them out so others are aware.Edit: Now that I’ve used it for a month I still love this stroller. I have been using the bassinet/back seat for my newborn so that he is not strapped into his car seat the whole time and he sleeps well plus a bottle, blanket, teddy bear all stay inside. It only has one parent cup holder, 2 would be nice. When back seat is in bassinet style it’s almost impossible to get into the storage basket without taking baby out or make him sit up but you can get to it between the seats. Had it in heavy gravel recently which was difficult but that’s the small wheels compared to my jogging stroller.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 31, 2020
CommentsContent: This thing is awesome for the price! We have a 2001 Toyota Camry and the stroller fits in our trunk, though it doesn’t leave room for much else.My wife is 4’10”. We clicked our baby’s car seat into the back seat of the stroller, facing backwards (the only way it will go), and she couldn’t see him when standing normally. She had to either go on tippy-toes and lean over the handlebar, or squat down and look through the window. So if she wants to make eye contact with him standing normally, she has to put him in the front seat. Just be aware of that if you’re short.What I love:-Front and back seats both accept Graco click-connect car seats.-It truly does stand up on its own when folded, and it’s surprisingly stable. Not insanely stable (don’t let your kids play around it), but way more than I anticipated.-It’s really fun to drive. Feels like I’m driving a limo.-I love that the back seat can turn into a bassinet for a small baby to lay in. In general, the stroller is very versatile, which makes it fun.-I love that the back seat reclines totally flat. When it’s reclined, you can’t access the cargo area from the main access point, but that hasn’t bugged me yet. I just lift the seat up or pull the cargo out from the side.-Tons of cargo storage space underneath. Way more than what we’re used to.-It’s not too heavy for my 4’10” wife to wrestle into and out of our car.-There’s a tinted plastic window to be able to see into the back seat from the driver’s view.Don’t love:-The rear seat’s sunshade, when pulled fully back, covers the cup holder zone of the person pushing the stroller. If you push the sun shade forward, it will either flop back where it was by itself, or it will fall forward a little, over the kid (and blocking your view of him/her).-The front sunshade leaves a gap between the front and back seats. It’s not as air-tight at the back sun shade. So for example we clicked my baby in the front seat while in his car seat, facing backwards (so looking at us), then extended the car seat’s sun shade all the way it would go, and then extended the stroller’s sun shade all the way it would go. They just barely met in the middle (I’d prefer that the stroller shade overlaps the car seat shade and extends beyond it), and there is still a gap in the back of the stroller’s shade that allows us to see straight into his little zone. This means that on a cold day, we can’t seal him in completely to keep the cold air out, or even rain if it’s windy while raining.-Getting the latch to latch when folding it up is surprisingly difficult for us.-Same thing when opening—I really have to pull hard on the little latch, and I’m scared I’ll pull too hard or in the wrong way and break it.-The front wheels do that thing where they shudder back and forth while you push, but it’s very slight. It could be because of weight distribution, but still it gives the stroller a cheap feel.-The wheels and hubs look like they came from a toy store—very plasticky and much smaller diameter than I anticipated.-If you dangle anything from the handlebars (eg, we have a diaper bag that’s actually a backpack, which we click onto the handlebar to keep it handy), then it will interfere with reclining the back seat down. Bummer.We love the stroller despite its quirks and we’ll run it until it falls to pieces. Thank you Graco for making a Disneyland-compliant double stroller for my family!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 11, 2019
CommentsContent: So, if you want a double stroller that can accept an infant car seat, this is about the lightest and most compact out there.  Those were the two defining factors for our family choosing this double stroller.  It was super convenient that it was also the most economic.Again, if you don't require your double stroller to connect with an infant car seat, there are plenty of other options that are much lighter.Pros:  I have been using our stroller for a bit over a month now.  I am quite impressed with the maneuverability. We switch up who sits where depending on our needs. That means I have tried out maneuverability with the heavier child both in front and in the back, as well as our four year old in the front seat.  My four year old in the front seat does greatly change the ease of pushing.  However, we bought this stroller for our newborn and two year old.  I have driven this in dirt and over sand (with only our infant in the stroller), and have found it to be no problem.  I drive in and out of doors by myself with my two younger children in the stroller and have found it easy to pass through a single door with no stags.  If our two year old is likely to want to sleep, we place him in the back seat., otherwise we sit him in the front.  Another bonus feature is the rear seat turns into a bassinet.  We use this bassinet feature often, since we live in SW Florida and it is cooler for our infant vs the infant car seat.  Also I really appreciate that the front seat sun shade pivots, so the front passenger can always escape our scalding hot sun.Cons (and constructive criticism): So as to folding and storage I give this a four star...only because I have tried out three other double strollers. for a travel system style this is about as good as you get.  I have only in the past week successfully locked/hooked/latched this stroller in its folded state.  It was a real bear up until recently when both my husband and I started to notice that it was becoming easier.  I can only hope this will keep improving with use, as not being able to lock a folded stroller is a huge pain in the back (for real).  Is it light? No! Is it light in comparison with others that serve the same function, yes.  So don't gripe about a double travel system stroller being heavy. At least for now the options are heavy, heavier and Plymouth Rock.  I finally was able to lock it by placing it against my trunk and leaning into it to latch it closed.  The photos  provided show how we travel with the stroller in our Honda Odyessey.  So I can only hope this may help some of you out there gain space in your trunks.  As you can see we use a bungee cord wrapped around the stroller and hooked around the metal polls of the seat headrest.Also I wish these companies would sit down with me so I could design a super star stroller, or at least to have an engineer explain why some basic adjustments are not possible.  For example: why are sunshades not full coverage?! (like in the Zoe's strollers) As far as I can tell it would only be the addition of cloth and maybe a zipper.  It is super annoying trying to keep the sun off of my infant in the bassinet on a sunny breezy day....as the blanket method turns more complicated. also why can the front seat not be taller, to accommodate an older child more comfortably?  Also why does the rear seat only have seating and lay flat positions?  My single graco stroller (That I still love and use with baby #3) has a single hand press that allows for any recline that I find convenient.  And finally I would like to understand why, in 2019, double strollers must still be so heavy to accommodate an  infant stroller when my graco single is only 17lbs and Zoe's double (not infant carseat adaptable) is 17 lbs....it seams that there should be a way to make it work.I am content with our purchase and see this as being a great options, not just for the price.  Pricier strollers could not be that much better to make the substantial price difference worth it.

CommentsTitle: Great deal &does the job. Ideal for indoor/zoo, not day to day.
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 14, 2020
CommentsContent: I use this product with my 2 year old and 3 month old, and I have been using it since my younger child was born. I love that the back seat lays flat for the baby, reclines very far back on the front seat, and that it will grow with my kids. This stroller is great in malls, because of the inline design, and would be great at a theme park or zoo with mostly flat ground and no bumps. This stroller is great for the price, however there are a few things I wish I would have known about before purchasing:I wish the front seat were a little taller, my son is on the short side, and still hits the back of his head on the back seat's tray when the front seat is reclined.Trying to get it up any bumps is challenging, because the back seat recline is so far out over the storage area and back tires that it catches my knee cap as I try to put pressure on the back tires to 'wheelie' the front tires up. I also found that it tries to tip to the side a lot if using it for walks around the neighborhood where the sidewalk slants for driveways. Now we just walk in the road to avoid this issue.The parent compartment doesn't hold much, and would honestly work better if it was just an open area. The cup holder is too shallow to really hold any beverage, and water bottles have fallen onto the back seat's sun canopy when going over the slightest bump.While I love that the back seat goes so flat, I don't love that the recline function for the seat requires two hands to engage. (A catch system located on either side). It would be much more convenient with the same recline system used on the front seat, since the child in the back seat is usually in my arms to begin with, and the seat has to be locked in the upright position for the stroller to lock folded. Speaking of which, while it is easy to fold, it is not easy to get it to latch closed. We found we had to have both seats in the upright position, fold it, and then basically kneel on it to get it to latch. While doable, it was a bit frustrating until we figured it out.Basically, if you plan to use the stroller for trips and family outings to flat places, and just need something the contain your children comfortably, this would be great for you! If you like to walk around the neighborhood and need something that can easily go over small bumps like the entry to the front of your house, and maneuver well over driveway slants, you may want to look elsewhere.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States April 29, 2018
CommentsContent: LOVE this stroller so far! Trust the good reviews. Its affordable compared to others and made as well as a double stroller can be made in my opinion. I spent days researching double strollers and I'm glad I picked this one! Reasons I chose this stroller and what I love about it:- Comfortability is perfect for the age difference of my kids. I have a newborn and I have an extremely tall 2 year old; shes as big as or bigger than most 3- 4 year olds and fits this perfectly, plus room to grow. I really didn't want my overgrown toddler to feel crammed. (I was originally between this and the BabyTrend Double Stroller to avoid something too bulky but I saw it in person at the store and felt like the front seat was just too small. I was also  between this and the Sit and Stand double strollers, but this is MUCH more suitable for younger toddlers who will still want to nap or just sit back on long trips or walks.)- GREAT SIZE. For a double stroller this one really is not that bulky or heavy! Handling this stroller is hassle free and fits in compact vehicle trunks just fine with room to spare. Yes, it's a little long but cmon guys it's a DOUBLE stroller, expect that when in the market for these. I noticed it's shorter if I have the car seat in the rear and my toddler in the front. The bottom storage basket is also spacious.-Assembly was easy with simple instructions. I was over 40 weeks pregnant and put it together by myself no problem. Just follow the manual.-Ease of use. It really does fold up nicely with one hand and stands on its own. Also opens up easily. In order for it to fold up nicely I do suggest removing the kids cup holder trays and front shade visor, which is super easy. Kind of like how it comes when you take it out of the box.- Maneuvers extremely well! I cut all kinds of sharp narrow corners with this thing.- Design and Reclining Features. I LOVE that the rear seat reclines all the way and has a fold up flap to enclose it completely. Perfect for laying a smaller baby down for a nap. The front seat also reclines well enough for a toddler to nap in (if there isn't a car seat in the rear).- Accessories. All these cupholder trays are awesome to have! Very convenient for every one. Just not sure how well the cup holders will fit the size of certain sippy cups though. But definitely not a deal breaker when it comes to buying one of these.Now for the cons I've found so far:- No shoulder straps! Only harnesses across their lap and between their legs. I read about it before buying. This was almost a deal breaker for me but my toddler is big enough for me not to worry about it too much. Not sure how this will affect my newborn as he grows into a bigger baby though.- As other reviewers noted, you can't really get into the bottom basket if the rear seat is reclined... which is how it has to be if you want a car seat in the rear seat close to you or if baby is asleep there.-Not much leg room for a child in the rear seat if a car seat is in the front. This makes it hard for my toddler to get out and her shoe comes off every time I try to pull her out. However it's kinda useful when I take them to out the stores and I want my toddler to stay put cus she literally can't get out ;pOther than that I didn't notice any problems or deal breakers for my preference. This review is completely based on my own experience and opinions. Overall I would highly recommend this product to a family in search of a spacious, durable, light weight double stroller. I've only been using it for a couple months but I can't imagine what I'd do without it now!
